mine.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: used by the person speaking or writing to refer to something that belongs to or is connected with himself or herself
mine.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: It was Glen’s idea, not mine.
‘Is that your car?’ ‘No, mine is parked over the road.’
You’ve got good legs – mine are too thin.
His English is better than mine.
I want you to meet an old friend of mine.
mine.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: a deep hole or holes in the ground that people dig so that they can remove coal, gold, tin etc
mine.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: one of the largest coal mines in the country
the time when children used to work down the mines
mine.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: a type of bomb that is hidden just below the ground or under water and that explodes when it is touched
mine.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: They learnt how to lay mines (=put them in place).
The ship struck a mine and sank.
mine.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: to dig large holes in the ground in order to remove coal, gold etc
mine.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: Copper has been mined here since the sixteenth century.
This area has been mined for over 300 years.
The company first started mining for salt in 1851.
mine.translation[2].definitions[0].note_: Mine is often passive in this meaning when used as a transitive verb
mine.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: to hide bombs in the sea or under the ground
mine.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: All the roads leading to the village had been mined.
mine.translation[2].definitions[1].note_: Mine is usually passive in this meaning
mine.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: a deep hole or series of holes that are dug in the ground in order to find gold, coal, diamonds etc
mine.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: The closure of the coal mines caused a lot of unemployment in the area.
mine.translation[4].definitions[0].defin: to dig holes or passages under the ground in order to obtain gold, coal, diamonds etc
